admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific
trustfund:
TF034917-INDONESIA - POWER DISTRIBUTION
            IN JAVA,TF034857-INDONESIA - SUMATERA I POWER
            WILAYAHS III AND IV

abstracts.cdata!:
The project ratings gave mixed results,
            for although its outcome is unsatisfactory, and
            sustainability is unlikely, substantial institutional
            development impacts were assessed, in view of greater
            management decentralization, and the creation of more
            autonomous business units. In addition, the performances of
            both the Bank, and Borrower were rated as satisfactory,
            given the strong, and continuous dialogue with the
            Government, who focused on much more than the agreed project
            objectives, identifying sector issues discussed with the
            State Electricity Corporation. Lessons reinforce the need
            for full Government commitments, to enhance coordination
            among suppliers, contractors, consultants, and donors, and
            achieve appropriate management capacity. Conversely, the
            successful Bank responsiveness to the financial crisis,
            through an increase of loan disbursement percentages for
            local expenditures, was instrumental in avoiding potential
            delays due to shortage of counterpart funds. But, realistic,
            and sound project cost estimates would have certainly
            avoided the large amounts of loan cancellations.
            Furthermore, the high cost of the Independent Power Producer
            to meet its financial objective, indicate the need for risk
            analysis, and, the use of a "rate of return on revalued
            assets" covenant to measure financial performance, is
            not appropriate for an entity with a very large investment program.
